comment._content: Here's a photo on dublin dot ie forums showing this corner. Abrahams was #1 Dame Street, the laneway at right is Foster Exchange Court, as seen on the OS 25" map.

comment._content: Carnival novelties department! One pair chattering teeth, one rubber chicken, some fake vomit and an exploding cigar please! I love it.

comment.author: 60765183@N08
comment._content: Maurice Abrahams is now located in South Anne Street. The business is run by Mr Abrahams's son Declan and it is one of the best mens shops in Dublin. www.menswear.ie/

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/60765183@N08] Abraham's website says "since 1962", which suggests that Rasher's photo I linked to upthread must be before that (which we would suspect from the green bus livery and the cool cars, but anyhow...)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/60765183@N08] Thanks for that! So they didn't move very far.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: James O' Connor Solicitors docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:IEcgrxi-EOcJ:www.c... Interesting document drafted by James O'Connor & Co of 1 Dame Street for the GAA and the Kerry County Board in 1939 concerning the Sam Maguire Cup

comment.author: 73371644@N04
comment._content: Zero's Disco was in Wolfe Tone St. "Brush" Sheils used to play there, amongst others!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/73371644@N04] That's great to know! Another mystery solved, thank you. Added into the description above and I copied your comment onto our other photo with Zero's posters - hope that's ok?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 73371644@N04
comment._content: My pleasure.

comment.author: 92043892@N06
comment._content: Katie Abrahams who is Declans daughter and Maurice's grandaughter found this photo today of our first 'proper retail' shop(very first shop was in Mary Street in 1962)The photo  was taken when a compulsory purchase order by the council meant the whole block was to be knocked down to make way for the forecourt we now know beside Dublin Castle.And so,we progressed to 11 Parliament Street where we traded for about 20 years also opening our flagship Sth Anne Street shop where we still trade.Thanks to everyone here for finding this great photo for us!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92043892@N06] You're more than welcome, and thanks a million for getting in touch! Always delighted to hear from family members...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
